Hi everyone!

In a formalization project, I need to explicitly calculate the first 5 element of a set. It is roughly analogous to the following:

example : (Nat.nth Nat.Prime) '' Finset.range 5 = {2, 3, 5, 7, 11} := by
  sorry

This seems very scary to prove. What is the best way to approach these kind of problems?

A very inefficient decidability proof to show a related statement:

import Mathlib

theorem nthPrime_iff (n x : ℕ) : Nat.nth Nat.Prime n = x ↔ Nat.count Nat.Prime x ≤ n ∧ n < Nat.count Nat.Prime (x+1) := by
  simp [← Finset.mem_Ico, Nat.lt_nth_iff_count_lt, Nat.count_le_iff_le_nth, Nat.infinite_setOf_prime]

instance inefficientDecidableNthPrime (n x : ℕ) : Decidable (Nat.nth Nat.Prime n = x) :=
  decidable_of_iff' _ (nthPrime_iff n x)

example : [0,1,2,3,4].map (Nat.nth Nat.Prime) = [2, 3, 5, 7, 11] := by
  simp +decide
You can (and should!) write better decidability instances if you want better performance, but I think that illustrates the point

Building on that here is a proof of your statement (maybe not very clean though):

import Mathlib

theorem nthPrime_iff (n x : ℕ) : Nat.nth Nat.Prime n = x ↔ Nat.count Nat.Prime x ≤ n ∧ n < Nat.count Nat.Prime (x+1) := by
  simp [← Finset.mem_Ico, Nat.lt_nth_iff_count_lt, Nat.count_le_iff_le_nth, Nat.infinite_setOf_prime]

instance inefficientDecidableNthPrime (n x : ℕ) : Decidable (Nat.nth Nat.Prime n = x) :=
  decidable_of_iff' _ (nthPrime_iff n x)

example : (Nat.nth Nat.Prime) '' Finset.range 5 = {2, 3, 5, 7, 11} := by
  simp_rw [← Finset.coe_image, Finset.range_succ]
  simp only [Finset.range_zero, insert_emptyc_eq, Finset.image_insert, Nat.nth_prime_one_eq_three,
    Finset.image_singleton, Nat.nth_prime_zero_eq_two, Finset.coe_insert, Finset.coe_singleton]
  have h1 : Nat.nth Nat.Prime 2 = 5 := by decide
  have h2 : Nat.nth Nat.Prime 3 = 7 := by decide
  have h3 : Nat.nth Nat.Prime 4 = 11 := by decide
  rw [h1, h2, h3]
  aesop

Similar version:

import Mathlib

theorem nthPrime_iff (n x : ℕ) : Nat.nth Nat.Prime n = x ↔ Nat.count Nat.Prime x ≤ n ∧ n < Nat.count Nat.Prime (x+1) := by
  simp [← Finset.mem_Ico, Nat.lt_nth_iff_count_lt, Nat.count_le_iff_le_nth, Nat.infinite_setOf_prime]

instance inefficientDecidableNthPrime (n x : ℕ) : Decidable (Nat.nth Nat.Prime n = x) :=
  decidable_of_iff' _ (nthPrime_iff n x)

example : (Nat.nth Nat.Prime) '' Finset.range 5 = {2, 3, 5, 7, 11} := by
  suffices hl : (List.range 5).map (Nat.nth Nat.Prime) = [2, 3, 5, 7, 11] by
    convert congrArg (·.toFinset.toSet) hl
    · norm_cast
    · simp
  simp +decide [List.range_succ]

Edit: Replaced the type ascription by an explicit .toSet call following @Chris Wong's suggestion.
Huh, that's funny! I reused my inefficient decidability instance from #new members > ∃N, N=(p1*p2*p3*...*pn)+1, p∊P, N∉P, also from May 2024. The solution in the thread you linked to is much better.
That congrArg can also be written as congr($(hl).toFinset.toSet)... which isn't really more readable, but might be worth knowing about.

nthPrime_iff is great for another decide-based proof @Mauricio Collares:

import Mathlib

theorem nthPrime_iff (n x : ℕ) : Nat.nth Nat.Prime n = x ↔ Nat.count Nat.Prime x ≤ n ∧ n < Nat.count Nat.Prime (x+1) := by
  simp [← Finset.mem_Ico, Nat.lt_nth_iff_count_lt, Nat.count_le_iff_le_nth, Nat.infinite_setOf_prime]

example : (Nat.nth Nat.Prime) '' Finset.range 5 = {2, 3, 5, 7, 11} := by
  have : (Finset.range 5 : Set Nat) = {0,1,2,3,4} := by ext; simp; omega
  rw [this]
  simp only [Set.image_insert_eq, Set.image_singleton]
  congr! <;> rw [nthPrime_iff] <;> decide

Thanks a lot for your responses. This was insightful, but my problem continues. Let me just copy paste the code:

Why decide doesn't work for this case?

import Mathlib

open Finset Nat

def P (n : ℕ) := ∃ p ∈ List.range (n + 1), p.Prime ∧ n = p^3

instance : DecidablePred P := by
  unfold P
  infer_instance

theorem infinite_setOf_P : {n | P n}.Infinite := by
  apply Set.Infinite.mono (s := (fun p ↦ p^3) '' {p | p.Prime})
  · rintro n ⟨p, hpp, rfl⟩
    unfold P
    refine ⟨p, ?_, hpp, rfl⟩
    rw [List.mem_range, Nat.lt_succ]
    apply Nat.le_self_pow (by norm_num)
  · apply Set.Infinite.image
    · intro _ _ _ _ h
      simpa using h
    · exact Nat.infinite_setOf_prime

theorem nthP_iff (n x : ℕ) :
    (Nat.nth P n) = x ↔ (Nat.count P x) ≤ n ∧ n < (Nat.count P (x+1)) := by
  simp [←mem_Ico, lt_nth_iff_count_lt, count_le_iff_le_nth, infinite_setOf_P]

example : Nat.nth P 0 = 8 := by
  decide

You didn't write a Decidable instance, so decide is using docs#instDecidableEqNat.

open Finset Nat

def P (n : ℕ) := ∃ p ∈ List.range (n + 1), p.Prime ∧ n = p^3

instance : DecidablePred P := by
  unfold P
  infer_instance

theorem infinite_setOf_P : {n | P n}.Infinite := by
  apply Set.Infinite.mono (s := (fun p ↦ p^3) '' {p | p.Prime})
  · rintro n ⟨p, hpp, rfl⟩
    unfold P
    refine ⟨p, ?_, hpp, rfl⟩
    rw [List.mem_range, Nat.lt_succ]
    apply Nat.le_self_pow (by norm_num)
  · apply Set.Infinite.image
    · intro _ _ _ _ h
      simpa using h
    · exact Nat.infinite_setOf_prime

theorem nthP_iff (n x : ℕ) :
    (Nat.nth P n) = x ↔ (Nat.count P x) ≤ n ∧ n < (Nat.count P (x+1)) := by
  simp [←mem_Ico, lt_nth_iff_count_lt, count_le_iff_le_nth, infinite_setOf_P]

instance {n x : Nat} : Decidable ((Nat.nth P n) = x) := decidable_of_iff' _ (nthP_iff n x)

example : Nat.nth P 0 = 8 := by
  decide
